p: Identification of the avian influenza A(H7N9) virus was first reported in March 2013, when three Chinese nationals were hospitalized with a severe lower respiratory tract disease of unknown cause [ 23]. Two patients from Shanghai (identified with strains A/Shanghai/1/2013 and A/Shanghai/2/2013) died within six days of hospital admission, while the third from Anhui Province, east of Shanghai (A/Anhui/1/2013), died 19 days after admission. This event was the first sign of a newly emerging virus that had the potential to be severely pathogenic within the human population [ 23].
